prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral image of the CO v=0 J=2->0 emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The CO line is expected to be a few km/s wide hence 1 km/s is a sensible resolution. Likewise for the CH3OH (methanol) line which we added as a bonus. We added a 1.9-GHz continuum band to help extracting line fluxes, and in its own right to map continuum thermal and non-thermal emission.

The SEST detection of CO(2-1) by Banas et al. (1997) was marginally resolved in the 23" beam (the Mopra CO(1-0) beam was 45"). Thus the primary beam of ALMA of more than 50" is sufficient to cover all of the region of interest in a single pointing. The CO may be structured on similar scales as seen in optical and infrared images; keeping in mind the observing times and the danger of over-resolving we thus settle on an optimal angular resolution of 2".

The SEST detection of CO(2-1) by Banas et al. (1997) peaked at 0.75 K and was marginally resolved in the 23" beam. Thus the primary beam of ALMA of more than 50" is sufficient to cover all of the region of interest in a single pointing. With a CO(2-1)-to-CO(1-0) ratio of about 0.5 for clouds of this mass (Chiar et al. 1994) we would have expected CO(1-0) to peak around 1.5 K, which is consistent with our Mopra CO(1-0) data peaking around 2 K km/s using twice as large a beam. We thus aim for a sensitivity of 0.06 K per resolution element of 2" and 1 km/s; we expect to detect most of the CO at signal-to-noise of a few, but with high surface brightness filaments yielding significantly larger signal-to-noise and hence more accurate kinematic and excitation information. The CO line is expected to be a few km/s wide hence 1 km/s is a sensible resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral image of the CO v=0 J=2->1 emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The CO line is expected to be a few km/s wide hence 1 km/s is a sensible resolution. We place an additional spectral window on the SiO(5-4) line, as a bonus without detrimental effect on the CO measurement. Likewise we added a 13CO line; all these lines are expected to have similar width of a few km/s. We added a 1.9-GHz continuum band to help extracting line fluxes, and in its own right to map continuum thermal and non-thermal emission.

The SEST detection of CO(2-1) by Banas et al. (1997) was marginally resolved in the 23" beam (the Mopra CO(1-0) beam was 45" and ASTE CO(3-2) beam was 27"). Thus the primary beam of ALMA of 27" is not quite sufficient to cover all of the region of interest in a single pointing, and we therefore make a tiny map of 40"x40" with half a beam spacings. The CO may be structured on similar scales as seen in optical and infrared images; keeping in mind the observing times and the danger of over-resolving we thus settle on an optimal angular resolution of 2". We request the use of the ACA to provide small-spacings information on scales of about 20" as such scales are too large for the 12m array at 230 GHz.

The SEST detection of CO(2-1) by Banas et al. (1997) peaked at 0.75 K and was marginally resolved in the 23" beam. The emission could be brighter in places if we further resolve it with ALMA, but some of it may be a lot fainter. We thus aim for a sensitivity of 0.02 K per resolution element of 2" and 1 km/s; we expect to detect most of the CO at signal-to-noise of a few, with high surface brightness filaments yielding significantly larger signal-to-noise and hence more accurate kinematic and excitation information. The CO line is expected to be a few km/s wide hence 1 km/s is a sensible resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SiO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral image of the SiO v=0 J=2->1 emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The SiO line is expected to be a few km/s wide hence 1 km/s is a sensible resolution. Likewise for the HCN and HCO+ lines which we added as a bonus. We added a 1.9-GHz continuum band to help extracting line fluxes, and in its own right to map continuum thermal and non-thermal emission.

The ALMA beam is more than an arcminute wide and covers all of the interaction region and in fact most of both the molecular cloud and the supernova remnant itself. Thus, any dust that is sputtered will be covered. The SiO may be structured on similar scales as seen in optical and infrared images; keeping in mind the observing times and the danger of over-resolving we thus settle on an optimal angular resolution of 2", i.e. identical to that in the CO lines.

The estimated amount of sputtered dust is of order 0.01 Msun. If a tenth of this remains present in the form of SiO molecules (a large fraction of the dust is in the form of silicates), then we expect of order 3x10^52 SiO molecules. If they are spread out over a 10"x10" region this yields a column density of 5x10^14 SiO molecules per cm^2. If resolved, the SiO emission brightness temperature is then expected to be of order 1 K (see, e.g., Lo et al. 2007). Because this is only a rough estimate and the goal is to determine the true value and distribution of SiO mass, we aim for a sensitivity level ten times below this, i.e. 0.1 K. (These estimates are consistent with our detections of SiO in the ALMA data of SN1987A - cf. Kamenetzky et al. 2013.) The SiO line is expected to be a few km/s wide hence 1 km/s is a sensible resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: LHA 120-N49 (N49) in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is the archetypical example of a supernova remnant (SNR) running into an interstellar molecular cloud. The shock manifests itself in X-rays, radio synchrotron radiation, optical and infrared fine structure lines and the heating and sputtering of dust grains, whilst the molecular cloud reveals itself by rotational emission from CO. Hence, N49 is one of the brightest SNRs in all of the Magellanic Clouds across the electromagnetic spectrum. Its position in the relatively unconfused Northern realms of the LMC lends it particularly well to a comprehensive and detailed study. One big obstacle to fully characterising the interaction is the absence of high angular and kinematic resolution images of the molecular emission. We propose to remedy this with ALMA maps of the CO and SiO emission at the collision interface at matching resolution to that of the extant multi-wavelength data. We will thus resolve the morphology, kinematics and excitation of the cloud collision and use - for the first time - SiO emission to trace the products of the sputtering of silicate grains and hence confirm the destructive nature of SNRs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.01120.S, "Resolving the collision of supernova remnant N49 with a molecular cloud", PI: Jacco van Loon (no time was awarded; the current proposal is an improved resubmission)
